5671.name: Grand Inga dam project, DRC
5671.shortDescription:
Mapping communities affected by dams construction projects

With a large number of hydroelectric dams construction projects in the DRC for national electrification, it turns out that the marine ecosystem could be disrupted with environmental and social consequences. This is the case of the Grand Inga hydroelectric dam, Busanga and Sombwe, whose estimates in terms of the social impacts of the surrounding communities are less clear.

It is with this in mind that Resource Matters, an international NGO, undertakes the initiative of mapping all the communities affected by the construction of several dams in order to enlighten the Congolese government but also the NGOs working for the protection of the local communities.

5673.name: Harare STI prevention: CHIEDZA project 3
5673.shortDescription:
- Author: **London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine**
- Map Features: `Buildings `

HIV infection is the leading cause of mortality among adolescents in Africa and this age-group is now a priority group for interventions. Zimbabwe has the 6th highest HIV prevalence globally and has had an early onset epidemic, resulting in current large numbers of adolescents with perinatally-acquired HIV. The CHIEDZA project, run by BRTI in Zimbabwe, is a community-based intervention, involving young people in the design and implementation and the whole continuum of HIV care including prevention, to improve HIV outcomes in adolescents.

5699.name: Brgy. Taliptip, Bulacan, Reclamation Target Area
5699.shortDescription: In 2018, the Philippine government received an unsolicited proposal from conglomerate San Miguel Corporation to build a large airport with a surrounding business district. The targeted area is part of a large deltaic wetland where many rural fishers live and work. If the airport project pushes through, it will require massive reclamation of wetland and mangrove areas. The loss of these environments will result in large-scale displacement of entire communities that rely on the coastal environment for their livelihood. This task aims to update the inhabited areas as well as the land use, structures, and road network of the potentially affected area.

5755.shortDescription: In and around Bossangoa in the Central African Republic, MSF teams provide consultations in hospitals and health centres, and support a network of community health workers all over the region. A better map of the region will help the teams to understand the exact situation in the area and will allow them to make rough population estimations.

5756.name: Paruro, Cusco - Women Connect Challenge Peru
5756.shortDescription: Peru has a very unequal society, and whilst parts of Peru are well mapped, these tend to be urban, wealthy areas that reflect the inter-sectional power relations at play in the country. GAL School Peru is training local high school students in Cusco to identify under-represented social issues, and then investigate, map and share them. To date, groups of school girls in Cusco have created campaigns that use maps of sexist publicity and behavior, presenting them as part of an international festival and to local government representatives, as well as peers and the broader school community. GAL will train 150 youth in mapping gendered issues, and work with local mayors in the Cusco region to better understand the experiences of girls in society.

5759.name: Missing Maps: Kenya, Kisii County, Bobasi Chache Ward
5759.shortDescription:
The American Red Cross is a member of the Measles & Rubella Initiative, which seeks to eliminate these diseases. We will be conducting intensive data collection activities in Kenya, in February/March 2019. This task will create a basemap of the area in order to help Red Cross teams to plan logistics and prepare for mobile data collection and field mapping in the areas. We will initially focus on these areas in Kisii and Starehe subcounties.

This task is also part of the Missing Maps project, which aims to map the most vulnerable places in the world (affected by humanitarian crises: disease epidemics, conflict, natural disasters, poverty, environmental crises). Building on HOT's disaster preparedness projects, the Missing Maps tasks facilitate pre-emptive mapping of priority countries to better facilitate disaster response, medical activities and resource allocation when crises occur.

A better map of the camp will allow the organisations supporting the refugees to respond more effectively and efficiently.

5782.name: Nicu Parish Buildings Mapping
5782.shortDescription:
Author: Missing Maps / HOT Uganda
* Requesting organization: UNHCR
* Imagery: Esri World Imagery
Escalations of violence in Democratic Republic of Congo and South Sudan have led to a large population movement into Uganda which continues daily. In a rapidly developing situation such as this, it is vital that accurate and up-to-date mapping information is available to allow the Emergency Response Units and local organisations to respond more effectively and efficiently.

The maps that you create in this task will enable sanitation facilities - including latrines, hand washing points and hygiene promotion activities - to be effectively provisioned for the people living there.

5783.name: Asutifi North District, Ghana WASH Project
5783.organisationTag: Conrad N. Hilton Foundation, CDC, Aquaya, WHO, ICF
5783.changesetComment: Asutifi North District, Ghana WASH Project #hotosm-project-5783 #CNHF #CDC #ICF #WHO #Aquaya #OSMGhana
5783.shortDescription: In order to meet WASH metrics for improved water and sanitation in Asutifi North District, Ghana, we need every structure in this area mapped so that we can track those that have piped water systems, those that are served by boreholes/pumps, and those that have no improved water source. If there are unmapped roads/tracks these would be very helpful also.

5786.name: Missing Maps: Teknaf, Cox's Bazar, Bangladesh, (JOSM: natural=wood)
5786.shortDescription:
`Intermediate mappers needed. Please only map in JOSM!`

- Author: **Missing Maps**
- Requesting Organization: **British Red Cross**


The Bangladesh Red Crescent Society (BDRCS) and British Red Cross (BRC) are partnering to support community Resilience through a Vulnerability to Resilience (V2R) programme in Teknaf, Cox's Bazar.

The V2R programme will take a multi sector approach with the aim that communities in Teknaf including locals and dispersed guest households live in harmony and that people have the capacity to meet their basic needs and deal with risks to enable their safety. The programme will also focus on mainstreaming protection, including enhancing awareness of human trafficking, and support BDRCS to better respond the emerging risks and hazards.

The map data will be used as a basemap to then add and improve infrastructure data in the communities. This data will be collected via a mobile survey. The improved OSM basemap will improve  the accuracy when adding the new features and its use in resilience programming.

5806.name: Accha, Cusco - Women Connect Challenge Peru
5806.shortDescription: Peru has a very unequal society, and whilst parts of Peru are well mapped, these tend to be urban, wealthy areas that reflect the inter-sectional power relations at play in the country. GAL School Peru is training local high school students in Cusco to identify under-represented social issues, and then investigate, map and share them. To date, groups of school girls in Cusco have created campaigns that use maps of sexist publicity and behavior, presenting them as part of an international festival and to local government representatives, as well as peers and the broader school community. GAL will train 150 youth in mapping gendered issues, and work with local mayors in the Cusco region to better understand the experiences of girls in society.

5835.shortDescription: In order to strengthen the teamwork and training new mappers for humanitarian and environmental causes, the Youthmappers chapters of Politecnico di Milano in Italy (Polimappers) and Universidad de Antioquia in Colombia (GeoLab UdeA), collaborate to map the human land-use of the natural corridor of the Andian mountains to the Amazon region, both ecosystems have strongly influenced the origin and maintenance of Neotropical biodiversity. Additionally, the Amazonian forest represents over half of the planet's remaining rainforests and comprises the largest and most biodiverse tract of tropical rainforest in the world.

5860.name: TZ_METEOR
5860.shortDescription:
The METEOR project is funded by the UK Space Agency and is comprised of GEM, the British Geological Survey (BGS), ImageCat, National Society for Earthquake Technology (NSET), The Disaster Management Department (DMD - Prime Minister's Office) of Tanzania, the Humanitarian OpenStreetMap Team (HOT) and Oxford Policy Management Limited (OPM).

The main objective of the project is to develop and deliver more accurate levels of the exposure of populations and the built environment to natural hazards in developing countries. The first pilot countries are Nepal and Tanzania, because of their differing exposure and hazard types. The project addresses Priority 1 of the Sendai Framework for DRR: Understanding disaster risk, with a specific aim to reach all 48 Least Developed ODA (Official Development Assistance).

5873.name: Mapping flood risk zones in kenédougou, Burkina Faso
5873.entitiesToMap: bâtiments, rues, Cours d'eau et plan d'eau
5873.shortDescription:
Burkina Faso is exposed to the effects of climate change. Hydrological risks, particularly floods, are a major concern in land use planning and management. In Burkina Faso's Kénédougou province, floods are one of the most dramatic manifestations of hydro-climatic variability. Indeed, the upward trend in rainfall seen in recent years has resulted in exceptionally serious disasters.
The international organization Action Against Hunger (ACF) is among the oldest to deal with this issue in Burkina Faso. It is planning the production of geographical data in the three communes of Kénédougou (Kayan, Morolaba and Kourouma) in order to prepare a response to disasters that could occur in the areas concerned.

5906.name: Grand Inga dam project (suite), DRC
5906.shortDescription:
Mapping communities affected by dams construction projects

With a large number of hydroelectric dams construction projects in the DRC for national electrification, it turns out that the marine ecosystem could be disrupted with environmental and social consequences. This is the case of the Grand Inga hydroelectric dam, Busanga and Sombwe, whose estimates in terms of the social impacts of the surrounding communities are less clear.

It is with this in mind that Resource Matters, an international NGO, undertakes the initiative of mapping all the communities affected by the construction of several dams in order to enlighten the Congolese government but also the NGOs working for the protection of the local communities.

5907.name: Cyclone Idai, West Zimbabwe Border: Buildings, Roads and Waterways
5907.shortDescription:
HOT has activated to support the disaster response operations of several Missing Maps partners responding to the impact of Cyclone Idai.

Cyclone Idai made landfall on 15 March in the city of Beira located in Central Mozambique. The cyclone wreaked havoc on Beira and its surrounding areas, resulting in significant damage and destruction to shelter and settlements, health, water and sanitation facilities, as well as large areas of crops.

This project is to digitize buildings, roads, and waterways around the Mozambique - Zimbabwe border affected by Cyclone Idai. Please use Bing imagery as it is the most recent and has little offset to existing roads.

5908.name: Cyclone Idai: Mozambique Border Buildings Update
5908.shortDescription:
`PROJECT RESTRICTED TO INTERMEDIATE MAPPERS`

HOT has activated to support the disaster response operations of several Missing Maps partners responding to the impact of Cyclone Idai in Mozambique, one of the worst humanitarian crises in Mozambique’s recent history.

Cyclone Idai made landfall on 15 March in the city of Beira located in Central Mozambique. The cyclone wreaked havoc on Beira and its surrounding areas, resulting in significant damage and destruction to shelter and settlements, health, water and sanitation facilities, as well as large areas of crops.

This project is to digitize buildings around the Mozambique - Zimbabwe affected by Cyclone Idai. Please use Bing imagery as it is the most recent and has little offset to existing roads.

5909.name: Quehue, Anna, Cusco - Women Connect Challenge Peru
5909.shortDescription: Peru has a very unequal society, and whilst parts of Peru are well mapped, these tend to be urban, wealthy areas that reflect the inter-sectional power relations at play in the country. GAL School Peru is training local high school students in Cusco to identify under-represented social issues, and then investigate, map and share them. To date, groups of school girls in Cusco have created campaigns that use maps of sexist publicity and behavior, presenting them as part of an international festival and to local government representatives, as well as peers and the broader school community. GAL will train 150 youth in mapping gendered issues, and work with local mayors in the Cusco region to better understand the experiences of girls in society.

5912.name: Missing Maps: Kamituga in South Kivu, Democratic Republic of Congo (Project 36)
5912.shortDescription:
The Democratic Republic of Congo is a priority country for the Missing Maps. South Kivu is a province of DRC that, for decades, has faced unceasing humanitarian crises. With constantly changing conflicts, seasonal disease epidemics and a population in constant flux, MSF and other NGOs have permanent presences here. 

There is no freely available mapping data available for the province, aside from that which has been already generously contributed by the HOT community in response to very specific crises. The Missing Maps has launched the Map South Kivu project to map the entire province, both remotely and through local community mapping. See [here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cjHYqY7OdXQ) for a video introduction to mapping South Kivu.

5927.name: Wajaale
5927.shortDescription:
Urbanization across the Somalia Region continues at an incredibly high rate, driven by high natural growth, migration, conflict and climate change. Urban centres are central places where basic social services such as water, health, education, public transport and roads are available. It is therefore essential to regulate urban growth, as a way to avoid new conflicts over scarce resources.

The UN Joint Program on Local Governance and Decentralized Service Delivery for Somalia (JPLG), which has five participating agencies including ILO, UNCDF, UNDP, UN-Habitat and UNICEF, has been building local government capacity in integrated urban planning processes in Somalia for the past ten years. 

The programme maintained the vision of reforming and strengthening sub-national structures as a means to consolidate peace gains, enhance delivery of basic urban services and restoring confidence and credibility in state institutions.

The Objective of this mapping project is to enrich the topographic data in Somalia with the aim to provide a base mapping of infrastructure and urban elements for the main district centers. This will support local administration in facilitating urban and district development planning, with the goal of improving basic service delivery and tackle from a spatial prospective displacement, poverty and environmental issues.

At the same time, this will also assist the UN mission in the country in their field endeavors, such as peace and security, navigation, and logistics by providing its peacekeepers with topographic maps that will help them in their tactical and operational activities.

5954.name: Grand Inga dam project, DRC (suite)
5954.shortDescription:
Mapping communities affected by dams construction projects

With a large number of hydroelectric dams construction projects in the DRC for national electrification, it turns out that the marine ecosystem could be disrupted with environmental and social consequences. This is the case of the Grand Inga hydroelectric dam, Busanga and Sombwe, whose estimates in terms of the social impacts of the surrounding communities are less clear.

It is with this in mind that Resource Matters, an international NGO, undertakes the initiative of mapping all the communities affected by the construction of several dams in order to enlighten the Congolese government but also the NGOs working for the protection of the local communities.

6015.name: Nebbi District, GPSDD Mapping
6015.shortDescription:
Author: Missing Maps / HOT Uganda
* Requesting organization: UNHCR
* Imagery: Esri World Imagery
Escalations of violence in the Democratic Republic of Congo and South Sudan have led to a large population movement into Uganda which continues daily. In a rapidly developing situation such as this, it is vital that accurate and up-to-date mapping information is available to allow the Emergency Response Units and local organisations to respond more effectively and efficiently.

The maps that you create in this task will enable sanitation facilities - including latrines, hand washing points and hygiene promotion activities - to be effectively provisioned for the people living there.

6067.name: Refugee Site Mapping Kakuma - Kenya (Zone 1)
6067.shortDescription:
The UN Refugee Agency (UNHCR) is assisting the Kenyan government in facing the challenges associated with this influx of refugees. Among other things, the UNHCR manages the establishment of refugee settlements, ensures access to basic facilities and provides humanitarian aid.
UNHCR has requested the assistance of CartONG and its community of volunteers to map several camps that do not yet appear on any map. This involves mapping houses/shelters and roads.

6071.name: Missing Maps: Mapear edificios, caminos y superficies de agua en el sur de Burundi 1 - parte oeste / Mapping buildings, roads and water surfaces in South Burundi 1 - west part
6071.shortDescription:
*Estas tareas están enmarcadas en un proyecto a largo plazo.*

Los equipos de Cruz Roja Española están solicitando mapear el sureste de Burundi. Los proyectos que se están desarrollando allí están relacionados con el fortalecimiento de la resiliencia de las poblaciones rurales en colaboración con los actores activos en seguridad alimentaria, nutrición, agua y saneamiento. El objetivo es reducir la inseguridad alimentaria y la malnutrición mejorando las condiciones socioeconómicas de los hogares en los que se implementen los proyectos.

6075.name: San Salvador, Calca - Women Connect Challenge
6075.shortDescription: Peru has a very unequal society, and whilst parts of Peru are well mapped, these tend to be urban, wealthy areas that reflect the inter-sectional power relations at play in the country. GAL School Peru is training local high school students in Cusco to identify under-represented social issues, and then investigate, map and share them. To date, groups of school girls in Cusco have created campaigns that use maps of sexist publicity and behavior, presenting them as part of an international festival and to local government representatives, as well as peers and the broader school community. GAL will train 150 youth in mapping gendered issues, and work with local mayors in the Cusco region to better understand the experiences of girls in society.

6147.name: Missing Maps - Uganda - Western - Sembabule West
6147.shortDescription:
hrough this mapping task the Netherlands Red Cross supports the Uganda Red Cross Society to:

    enhance** resilience** and building institutional disaster response capacity training for the people of Uganda

    raise awareness within vulnerable communities in disaster-prone areas of the possible dangers of natural disasters.

    improve the delivery of sustainable water supply, sanitation and hygiene services in these low-income areas

    respond to a food crisis to meet drought affected population’s food and nutrition needs through cash transfer.

Mapping efforts are coordinated with local government / members of the HOTOSM community in Uganda

The Missing Maps project aims to map the most vulnerable places in the world (affected by humanitarian crises: disease epidemics, conflict, natural disasters, poverty, environmental crises). Building on HOT's disaster preparedness projects, the Missing Maps tasks facilitate pre-emptive mapping of priority countries to better facilitate disaster response, medical activities and resource allocation when crises occur.

6150.name: Missing Maps: Kenya, Bomet County (north)
6150.shortDescription: Large-scale epidemics and pandemics pose a serious threat not only to global health security but also to countries, communities and individuals in their efforts to achieve resilience. Epidemics and pandemics affect all sectors, impacting routine health services, economic and food security, trade, education, civil order, communication, transportation, and many other areas of life.

6151.name: Missing Maps: Kenya, Bomet County (central and west)
6151.shortDescription:
- Author: **Missing Maps**
- Requesting Organization: **American Red Cross**

The Red Cross is mapping Bomet County in Kenya as part of a  data readiness activity to better understand where critical infrastructure and roads are to inform decision making during potential disasters. The map data will help the Red Cross to better understand where people live in relation to potential hazards so that we can help them be prepared for the disaster and so national decision makers can make better decisions in the immediate aftermath of a disaster.

6155.name: Missing Maps: Dengue fever in Honduras - San Pedro Sula 1
6155.shortDescription: Following a prolonged rainy season, Honduras is seeing a sharp increase in cases of dengue fever, with children particularly affected. To help bring the epidemic under control MSF is supporting community prevention efforts in one of the most affected regions as well as pediatric care at the Mario Catarino Rivas Hospital in San Pedro Sula, the second largest city in the country.

6163.name: Missing Maps: Spraying against Malaria - Ruyigi, Burundi
6163.shortDescription: In the end of August MSF will assist in an Indoor Residual Spraying (IRS) campaign in the south of the Ruyigi Province – Health District of Kinyinya in Burundi. During this campaign insecticides will be applied on the inside of dwellings where malaria infected mosquitos rest. As a result the number of mosquitos will go down, which prevents the transition of Malaria.

6174.name: Refugee Site Mapping Kakuma - Kenya (Zone 1)
6174.shortDescription:
The UN Refugee Agency (UNHCR) is assisting the Kenyan government in facing the challenges associated with this influx of refugees. Among other things, the UNHCR manages the establishment of refugee settlements, ensures access to basic facilities and provides humanitarian aid.
UNHCR has requested the assistance of CartONG and its community of volunteers to map several camps that do not yet appear on any map. This involves mapping houses/shelters and roads.

6175.name: Missing Maps: Dengue fever in Honduras - Choloma
6175.shortDescription: Following a prolonged rainy season, Honduras is seeing a sharp increase in cases of dengue fever, with children particularly affected. To help bring the epidemic under control MSF is supporting community prevention efforts in one of the most affected regions as well as pediatric care at the Mario Catarino Rivas Hospital in San Pedro Sula, the second largest city in the country.

6202.name: IOM POE Mapping, Kisoro District, Uganda
6202.shortDescription:
Author: Missing Maps / HOT Uganda
Requesting organization: HOT Uganda/IOM
Imagery: Esri World Imagery

The evolving Ebola situation in the DRC makes it extremely urgent to map all buildings and other infrastructure in towns and villages serving the borders. There is a severe lack of up-to-date and detailed maps of this area available to those involved in the fight to contain the outbreak.
Please work with those of us on the ground to collect this life-saving information by remotely tracing borderland infrastructure.

6203.name: Northern Syria - Roads and Waterways
6203.shortDescription: The scale, severity and complexity of the humanitarian needs of people in Syria remain extensive. This is the result of continued hostilities in localized areas, new and protracted displacement, increased self-organized returns and the sustained erosion of communities’ resilience during close to eight years of crisis.

6212.name: Building Resilient Communities in Bohol
6212.shortDescription:
The UP Resilience Institute (UPRI) was established in 2016 with a mission statement to empower local communities through multidisciplinary research and actions toward resilience. Last year, the UP Resilience Institute Youth Mappers was formally launched under the UPRI with the aim of mapping the communities using volunteered geographic information (VGI) and building the capacities of the local communities in order to fight real world problems such as poverty, disease, hunger, and disasters.

With our new project, “Building Resilient Communities in Bohol Through the Use of OpenStreetMap (OSM)”, we seek to improve the structures dataset including building footprints and road network and to produce municipal-level risk maps in the province of Bohol through the use of open-source tools such as OSM, QGIS, and WebSAFE that can be used for disaster risk planning and mitigation.  OSM and its associated mapping tools are effective at providing rapid support to local government unit efforts in disaster risk reduction and management, including strengthening of contingency plans and risk-sensitive land use plans.

6217.name: Missing Maps: Myanmar, Bago West, Pyay District
6217.shortDescription:
- Author: **Missing Maps**
- Requesting Organization: **American Red Cross**

The Red Cross is mapping the Ayeyarwady Delta area in Myanmar as part of a multi-year mapping and data readiness activity to better understand where critical infrastructure and roads are to inform decision making during potential disasters. As recently as 2008 a cyclone killed at least 77,000 people with over 55,900 missing, and left about 2.5 million homeless. The map data will help the Red Cross to better understand where people live in relation to potential hazards so that we can help them be prepared for the disaster and so national decision makers can make better decisions in the immediate aftermath of a disaster.
